conclusion: Objects A and B are moved through the air and placed on objects C, D, E, and F, where they come into contact due to gravity.
A is a blue prism, C is a purple cloth-covered prism, B is a red prism, and E is a grey cloth-covered dark block.
A (blue prism) is lowered until it rests on C (purple cloth-covered prism).
As soon as A arrives, gravity makes it settle firmly against the top surface of C.
B (red prism) is lowered until it rests on E (grey cloth-covered dark block).
Gravity likewise pulls B downward until it comes to rest on E.
When A and B are at rest, the four stationary blocks C, D, E, F each feel the additional vertical load coming from A and B.
No horizontal motion or toppling occurs because all blocks are shown upright with flat contacting faces, so the forces stay aligned with their centres of mass.
Net result: A is stably stacked on C-D, and B is stably stacked on E-F; the whole arrangement simply forms two small stacks of blocks.

Final answer: The two moving blocks A and B will land on the blocks that are already there (C–D under A, E–F under B) and will just remain resting on them under gravity, producing two stable vertical stacks.
